p.content: Verbs express actions, states, or emotions. The types of verbal inflection and agreement features carried by verbs are detailed first, then illustrative verb paradigms are presented. The issue of when a subject may be missing is discussed in section
, and auxiliaries are covered in section
, followed by verb compounds. Examples of the verbs used in basic sentences are found in section
. More complex constructions including verbs are covered in sections
Verbs and auxiliaries usually carry inflection features, such as tense, aspect, and/or mood. In most cases, these features are added by affixes, but they may also be part of irregular verb forms.
The following inflection features are marked on verbs and/or auxiliaries in

Verbs and auxiliaries may also carry agreement features that agree with the subject or the direct object. Most of these features are added by affixes or pronominal clitics which may attach to the verb.

text.content: Class agreement was handled in section

p.content: The following agreement features are marked on verbs and/or auxiliaries in
Paradigms display in table form some of the changes that occur when the inflection and agreement morphemes are added to particular verbs. Some verbs are verb regular, while others are irregular.
Paradigms for four regular verbs are shown here:
p.comment: You will need to add the forms in each cell. You can change verbs if these are not regular in your language. You can delete some columns if the table is too wide in the pdf output.

p.content: Paradigms for three irregular verbs are shown here:
p.comment: You will need to add the forms in each cell. You can change verbs if these are not expressed or not irregular in your language. Note that ‘to come’ may be ‘to go toward base’ and ‘to go’ may be ‘to go to non-base’ or ‘to go away from base’ in your language. You can delete some columns if the table is too wide in the pdf output.

p.content: Some languages are called pro-drop languages because they allow a subject and/or object to be missing or unexpressed in their normal syntactic position. For example, in Spanish the normal way to say “I buy a book” is
rather than with the overt subject pronoun included:
. This is not allowed in English, except for imperatives. (The missing subject of infinitives in embedded clauses will be covered in section

Some languages are not really pro-drop languages, but at least some of the pronouns are clitics which can attach to the verb. When this happens, there is no pronoun or nominal phrase in subject position, so the sentence appears the same as in a true pro-drop language.

Pro-drop languages allow a subject and/or object to be missing or unexpressed in their normal syntactic position. There are also languages where at least some of the pronouns are clitics which attach to the verb. When this happens, there is no pronoun or nominal phrase in subject position, so the sentence appears the same as in a true pro-drop language.
In

text.content: a missing subject (pro-drop) is allowed in any type of sentence.
Pro-drop of the object is
allowed.
the subject may look like it is missing due to dependent pronouns (pronominal clitics) attaching to the verb, but it is not a true pro-drop language.
a missing subject (pro-drop) is allowed in any type of sentence and there are also pronominal clitics which may attach to the verb.
Pro-drop of the object is
allowed.
a missing subject (pro-drop) is not allowed. The subject must be overt except in imperatives.
a missing subject (pro-drop) is allowed in any type of sentence, including imperatives.
Pro-drop of the object is
allowed.

the subject may look like it is missing due to dependent pronouns (pronominal clitics) attaching to the verb, but it is not a true pro-drop language. A completely missing subject is allowed in imperatives.
a missing subject (pro-drop) is allowed in any type of sentence, including imperatives, and there are also pronominal clitics which may attach to the verb.
Pro-drop of the object is
allowed.
a missing subject (pro-drop) is not allowed. The subject must be overt even in imperatives.
a missing subject is only allowed ___
a missing subject is allowed ___
and also in imperatives.
A missing subject is also allowed ___

There are several kinds of verbal auxiliary elements, including auxiliary words, as well as nonfinite, motion and other types.
Auxiliary elements that are written as independent words express some types of verbal inflection.
Some languages have auxiliary elements that are independent words, and some can have more than one auxiliary element before the main verb. Examples for English transitive sentences include:
p.langData: The boy will hit the ball
The boy might have hit the ball
p.content: and
p.langData: The boy might have been hitting the ball
p.content: . In other languages these are all expressed by verbal inflection.
auxiliaries which are written as independent words.

text.content: An auxiliary is
and
in a single clause.
After an auxiliary, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before an auxiliary, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

The nonfinite marker may also act as an auxiliary if it is written as an independent word.
The nonfinite word
used in English embedded clauses also acts as an auxiliary in that it fills the same position and can occur before other auxiliaries. For example,
p.langData: The boy would like to have hit the ball

case.caseText: does not have any marker for nonfinite clauses.
only marks the nonfinite feature as part of the verb.
has some nonfinite auxiliary-type markers which are written as independent words.

text.content: A nonfinite auxiliary word is
in nonfinte embedded clauses.
After a nonfinite auxiliary, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before a nonfinite auxiliary, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: The nonfinite auxiliary marker(s) in
is/are:
Examples of nonfinite clauses including these nonfinite auxiliaries are:
Other words may also act like auxiliaries, such as motion auxiliaries or loan markers.
Some languages have other words that act like auxiliaries, such as motion auxiliaries or loan markers, which share the same subject and complements as the main verb.
auxiliaries of this type which are written as independent words.

text.content: After one of these auxiliaries, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before one of these auxiliaries, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: These other auxiliaries in
are:

Verbs may combine with other verbs, or with nouns or other word categories to form verb compounds. These compounds still act like verbs, though they may have changed their valence, such as from a transitive verb to an intransitive verb. Examples of the most common types will be given here.
A special set of verb compounds all contain the noun which describes the center of emotions, such as the heart.

caption.content: Compounds with the Center of Emotions

p.content: A

text.content: nother

p.content: special set of verb compounds all contain a body part noun

text.content: other than the center of emotions

There are also idiomatic expressions consisting of a verb and another word that go together as a unit to express a notion that is not just the same as the combined meaning of the two independent words. Some examples of idioms in
are:
